entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10885
entry.itemBody: Which of the following changes most likely reflects a discretionary fiscal policy action?

answerFeedback.27d93c91-cc55-4eaf-b864-32955422cd91: Incorrect because automatic stabilizers—such as income tax, VAT, and social benefits—are important because as output and employment fall and reduce tax revenues, so net tax revenues also fall as unemployment benefits rise. This acts as a fiscal stimulus and serves to reduce the size of the multiplier, dampening the output response of whatever caused the fall in output in the first place. By their very nature, automatic stabilizers do not require policy changes; no policymaker has to decide that an economic shock has occurred and how to respond.
answerFeedback.96758ece-674f-4a32-a790-0bac8eb94ece: Correct because in addition to these automatic adjustments, governments also use discretionary fiscal adjustments to influence aggregate demand. These will involve tax changes and/or spending cuts or increase usually with the aim of stabilizing the economy. An increase in government expenditures due to new infrastructure projects is a discretionary fiscal policy action because new public spending on social goods and infrastructure, such as hospitals and schools, boosting personal incomes with the objective of raising aggregate demand.
answerFeedback.aa0a51c0-d712-4ad2-81c0-59fc51704315: Incorrect because the deficit can change for reasons unrelated to actual fiscal policy changes. Automatic stabilizers will lead to changes in the budget deficit unrelated to fiscal policy changes; a recession will cause tax revenues to fall and the budget deficit to rise.

choices.itemBody: A. A decrease in corporate tax revenues due to lower corporate profitability
B. An increase in government expenditures due to new infrastructure projects
C. An increase in payments of unemployment benefits due to increasing unemployment

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Bailey-11
entry.itemBody: With respect to fiscal policy, transfer payments are best described as:

answerFeedback.2723344d-cc19-4b5c-9191-111f18fb57e5: Incorrect because current government spending involves spending on goods and services that are provided on a regular, recurring basis—including health, education, and defense, not transfer payments.
answerFeedback.9f0ca29b-ec33-45bf-bf80-243eaca60838: Correct because transfer payments are welfare payments made through the social security system, and, depending on the country, comprise payments for state pensions, housing benefits, tax credits and income support for poorer families, child benefits, unemployment benefits and job search allowances.
answerFeedback.f49c0765-1b59-4fb9-9a12-9ac1606a169c: Incorrect because capital expenditure includes infrastructure spending on roads, hospitals, prisons, and schools, not transfer payments.

choices.itemBody: C. spending on recurring goods and services.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Econ-Young-13
entry.itemBody: A decline in tax revenues due to a recession is best described as an example of a(n):

answerFeedback.0c6f531a-a0dd-40ea-9c9c-956d2219e7a9: Incorrect because falling tax revenues due to a recession are an example of an automatic stabilizer. Automatic stabilizers will lead to changes in the budget deficit unrelated to fiscal policy changes; a recession will cause tax revenues to fall and the budget deficit to rise. An expansionary fiscal policy is discretionary in order to help manage the economy through its influence on aggregate national output, that is, real GDP. In a recession, governments can raise spending (expansionary fiscal policy) in an attempt to raise employment and output.
answerFeedback.0c77498e-710f-42ea-adbc-f8285b2d8ec5: Incorrect because falling tax revenues due to a recession are an example of an automatic stabilizer. Automatic stabilizers will lead to changes in the budget deficit unrelated to fiscal policy changes; a recession will cause tax revenues to fall and the budget deficit to rise. A contractionary fiscal policy is discretionary in order to help manage the economy through its influence on aggregate national output, that is, real GDP. When an economy has full employment and wages and prices are rising too fast—then government spending may be reduced and taxes raised (contractionary fiscal policy).
answerFeedback.ff2c713f-8673-4246-b56b-a98869dd98fc: Correct because falling tax revenues due to a recession is an example of automatic stabilizer, not a discretionary fiscal policy. Automatic stabilizers will lead to changes in the budget deficit unrelated to fiscal policy changes; a recession will cause tax revenues to fall and the budget deficit to rise.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Econ-Zipp-14
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an expansionary fiscal policy?

answerFeedback.1de51a7c-4ff2-4314-a12e-4b7fd0374d06: Correct because there are a number of ways that fiscal policy can influence aggregate demand. Expansionary policy could take the form of new public spending on social goods and infrastructure.
answerFeedback.6577193b-0537-4ef6-ae06-96b9bd3514b3: Incorrect because when the economy is slowing and inflation and monetary trends are weakening, central banks may increase liquidity by cutting their target (interest) rate. In these circumstances, monetary policy is said to be expansionary. Thus while expansionary, this is an example of monetary rather than fiscal policy.
answerFeedback.9122dedb-a473-4c90-b23e-e07bc339c25e: Incorrect because expansionary (fiscal) policy could take the form of cuts in sales (indirect) taxes to lower prices which raises real incomes with the objective of raising consumer demand. Thus, an increase in sales taxes would be contractionary, not expansionary.

choices.itemBody: C. An increase in public spending on infrastructure

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Econ-Young-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following fiscal policy actions is most likely contractionary?

answerFeedback.248c5b8a-4c37-44f3-a47f-9399946def62: Incorrect because decreasing taxes and increasing spending are indicative of a budget deficit, which is expansionary. An expansionary policy could take one or more of the following forms: cuts in sales (indirect) taxes to lower prices which raises real incomes with the objective of raising consumer demand, cuts in corporation (company) taxes to boost business profits, which may raise capital spending, and cuts in tax rates on personal savings to raise disposable income for those with savings, with the objective of raising consumer demand. Expansionary fiscal policy also includes new public spending on social goods and infrastructure, such as hospitals and schools, boosting personal incomes with the objective of raising aggregate demand. An increase in a budget surplus would be associated with contractionary fiscal policy, while a rise in a deficit is an expansionary fiscal policy.
answerFeedback.8ab9d485-b97f-4fcd-82dc-86245a03fa90: Incorrect because a decrease in taxes is expansionary, while a decrease in spending is contractionary. Without knowing the relative magnitudes, we cannot say whether the policy is expansionary or contractionary. An expansionary policy could take one or more of the following forms: cuts in sales (indirect) taxes to lower prices which raises real incomes with the objective of raising consumer demand, cuts in corporation (company) taxes to boost business profits, which may raise capital spending, and cuts in tax rates on personal savings to raise disposable income for those with savings, with the objective of raising consumer demand. However, an increase (not decrease) in spending is expansionary. Expansionary fiscal policy also includes new public spending on social goods and infrastructure, such as hospitals and schools, boosting personal incomes with the objective of raising aggregate demand. An increase in a budget surplus would be associated with contractionary fiscal policy, while a rise in a deficit is an expansionary fiscal policy.
answerFeedback.fca6ac1f-a9b4-498f-adfc-f14b1c4ac597: Correct because increasing taxes and decreasing spending are indicative of a contractionary fiscal policy. When an economy has full employment and wages and prices are rising too fast—then government spending may be reduced and taxes raised (contractionary fiscal policy).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08536
entry.itemBody: A fiscal policy tool that can immediately influence spending is most likely:

answerFeedback.5fc82072-dbe6-4253-8b40-5e38953cc7a2: Incorrect because capital spending plans take longer to formulate and implement, typically over a period of years. The slower the impact of a fiscal change, the more likely other exogenous changes will already be influencing the economy before the fiscal change kicks in.
answerFeedback.641a5678-cbe7-45cc-922e-ea06668a29b9: Correct because indirect taxes can be adjusted almost immediately after they are announced and can influence spending behavior instantly and generate revenue for the government at little or no cost to the government.
answerFeedback.8b87b73a-2113-4e85-ba71-c37a420abd10: Incorrect because exchange rate targeting is a monetary policy tool, not a fiscal policy tool. Many developing economies choose to operate monetary policy by targeting their currency's exchange rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-McDonald-06
entry.itemBody: An objective of fiscal policy is to:

answerFeedback.140d02e7-6b3f-488f-86e8-2f8e78f05ede: Incorrect because monetary policy (not fiscal policy) refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy.
answerFeedback.6f271a0e-0a3a-4913-b998-6a2477f4f009: Incorrect because fiscal policy refers to the government’s decisions about taxation and spending.  It is for central banks that there is one overarching objective that most seem to acknowledge explicitly, and that is the objective of maintaining price stability.
answerFeedback.df0d0432-cf9e-4655-b3c8-7d448165d407: Correct because fiscal policy can be used to redistribute income and wealth.

choices.itemBody: C. influence the quantity of credit in an economy.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Bailey-10
entry.itemBody: Which of the following government actions is most likely an expansionary fiscal policy?

answerFeedback.17e3df37-06cc-4b39-8714-d0d547ff73f6: Correct because a decrease in taxes, including tax on savings, would be expansionary fiscal policy. For example, an expansionary policy could take the form of cuts in tax rates on personal savings to raise disposable income for those with savings, with the objective of raising consumer demand.
answerFeedback.9932190d-f34e-4c43-8f55-6c20eab6d077: Incorrect because a decrease in public spending, including infrastructure, would not be an expansionary fiscal policy. For example, an expansionary policy could take the form of new public spending on social goods and infrastructure, such as hospitals and schools, boosting personal incomes with the objective of raising aggregate demand.
answerFeedback.b0a7a7e4-f139-494e-86cf-e0d8790cbf0e: Incorrect because an increase in taxes, including tax on sales, would not be expansionary fiscal policy. For example, an expansionary policy could take the form of cuts in sales (indirect) taxes to lower prices which raises real incomes with the objective of raising consumer demand.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Kassem-13
entry.itemBody: Monetary policy is used to:

answerFeedback.2e5e2847-5369-44d6-ba7a-f31d6ee44bac: Incorrect because fiscal policy, not monetary policy, is used to redistribute income and wealth. Monetary policy refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. Whereas fiscal policy can be used to redistribute income and wealth.
answerFeedback.5b2b81ea-befa-46e9-813a-7aa20381d0fb: Incorrect because fiscal policy, not monetary policy, determines taxation and spending. Monetary policy refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. Whereas fiscal policy refers to the government’s decisions about taxation and spending.
answerFeedback.e42e2c43-4197-4185-9d87-4175b510f934: Correct because the overarching goal of both monetary and fiscal policy is normally the creation of an economic environment where growth is stable and positive and inflation is stable and low.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Elkinawy-Young-09
entry.itemBody: An argument against being concerned about high national debt levels is that:

answerFeedback.01e69f12-84de-4924-a84f-ec0d3e31024d: Correct because this internally owed debt may overstate the problem. The arguments against being concerned about national debt (relative to GDP) include the following: The scale of the problem may be overstated because the debt is owed internally to fellow citizens.
answerFeedback.a1bef1aa-b129-4371-959c-7f3da37c5681: Incorrect because government borrowing leads to lower private sector investment. The arguments in favor of being concerned include: Government borrowing may divert private sector investment from taking place (an effect known as crowding out); if there is a limited amount of savings to be spent on investment, then larger government demands will lead to higher interest rates and lower private sector investing.
answerFeedback.c408ceb6-0d58-4017-838c-af18ebff7ceb: Incorrect because this is an argument against high national debt due to the risk of high inflation. The arguments in favor of being concerned include: If markets lose confidence in a government, then the central bank may have to print money to finance a government deficit. This may lead ultimately to high inflation.

choices.itemBody: A. the debt is owed internally to fellow citizens.
B. government borrowing leads to higher private sector investment.
C. the central bank can print money to finance a government deficit.

entry.title: CFA2412-R-s06-Q5

feedback.neutral: C is correct. A fall in interest rates is likely to lead to a rise in investment. Crowding out refers to government borrowing that reduces the ability of the private sector to invest.

entry.itemBody: Crowding out refers to a:

choices.itemBody: A. fall in interest rates that reduces private investment.
B. rise in private investment that reduces private consumption.
C. rise in government borrowing that reduces the ability of the private sector to access investment funds.

entry.title: CFA2412-R-s06-Q6

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Note that a reduction in government spending could be accompanied by an even bigger fall in taxation, making it be expansionary.

entry.itemBody: A contractionary fiscal policy will always involve which of the following?

choices.itemBody: C. Fall in the budget deficit or rise in the surplus

entry.title: CFA2412-R-s06-Q7

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Note that governments often allow pressure groups to affect fiscal policy and that Ricardian equivalence involves individuals correctly anticipating future taxes. Thus, A and B are not correct choices.

entry.itemBody: Which one of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.itemBody: A. Ricardian equivalence refers to individuals having no idea of future tax liabilities.
B. Governments do not allow political pressures to influence fiscal policies but do allow voters to affect monetary policies.
C. If there is high unemployment in an economy, then easy monetary and fiscal policies should lead to an expansion in aggregate demand.

entry.title: CFA2412-R-s06-Q8

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Cyclically adjusted budget deficits are appropriate indicators of fiscal policy. These are defined as the deficit that would exist if the economy was at full employment (or full potential output).

entry.itemBody: Which statement regarding fiscal policy is most accurate?

choices.itemBody: A. Cyclically adjusted budget deficits are appropriate indicators of fiscal policy.
B. To raise business capital spending, personal income taxes should be reduced.
C. An increase in the budget surplus is associated with expansionary fiscal policy.

entry.title: CFA2412-R-s06-Q9

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Fiscal policy is subject to recognition, action, and impact lags.

entry.itemBody: The least likely explanation for why fiscal policy cannot stabilize aggregate demand completely is that:

choices.itemBody: A. private sector behavior changes over time.
B. policy changes are implemented very quickly.
C. fiscal policy focuses more on inflation than on unemployment.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531101
entry.itemBody: The crowding-out effect is most likely associated with:

answerFeedback.558dcd6f-d560-49a1-b76c-0820a2f949e9: Correct. The tendency for government borrowing to decrease private sector investment is called the crowding-out effect.
answerFeedback.646058fb-159f-4cb1-8e7b-f7ac2b83bdfb: Incorrect. The tendency for government borrowing to decrease private sector investment is called the crowding-out effect.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531104
entry.itemBody: If a government increases its spending on domestically produced goods by an amount that is financed by an equivalent increase in taxes, the aggregate demand will most likely:

answerFeedback.2724a0d1-26fa-4a34-8ee6-b25e2ab46b02: Correct. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c. This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect.
answerFeedback.92ee915f-8332-4a75-9f59-4fab1d657ad7: Incorrect. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c. This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect.
answerFeedback.e3e6751e-437c-4629-9574-c54e457d699b: Incorrect. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c. This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531106
entry.itemBody: In a hypothetical economy, consumption is 70% of pre-tax income, and the average tax rate is 25% of total income. If planned government expenditures are expected to increase by $1.25 billion, the increase in total income and spending, in billions, is closest to:

answerFeedback.7c90b33d-468c-49b2-990e-800559450057:
Correct.

The fiscal multiplier is  where

c = marginal propensity to consume = consumption/disposable income

T = the tax rate

It calculates the MPC from pre-tax income (MPC = 0.70) and applies the formula: 1/[1 – c(1 –T)]: 1/[1 – 0.70(1 – 0.25)] = 2.10; resulting in an overall stimulus effect of 2.10 × 1.25 = 2.60.
answerFeedback.ac488bc5-7771-4020-9b2b-0cc3950586f3:
Incorrect

This approach incorrectly recalculates the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) as $70 / $75 = 0.933,

where,

Assuming pre-tax income of $100

Disposable income: $100 × (1 – 0.25) = $75

Marginal propensity to consume: $70/$75 = 0.933

The fiscal multiplier: 1/[1 – 0.933(1 – 0.25)] = 3.33

With government expenditure of $1.25 billion, total incomes and spending will rise by $1.25 billion × 3.33 = $4.2 billion.

This treats the original 0.70 (which was based on pre-tax income) as consumption out of disposable income. However, the fiscal multiplier formula already adjusts for taxes using the term c(1 − t). Recalculating MPC in this way double-counts the effect of taxes and overstates the multiplier.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531133
entry.itemBody: The primary goal of both monetary and fiscal policy focuses on balancing economic growth and:

answerFeedback.6a1c2299-2c49-4bc7-9beb-b8f99b2df7be: Incorrect because the overarching goal of monetary and fiscal policy is to create economic conditions characterized by positive, stable economic growth and low, stable inflation. Achieving this goal promotes stability (rather than cyclicality) in employment, consumption, and saving/investment outcomes.
answerFeedback.b4b5d92e-6cb6-4f44-b554-0fa46ac681b4: Correct. The goal of both monetary and fiscal policy is the creation of an economic environment characterized by positive, stable growth and low, stable inflation.
answerFeedback.f221206f-bde8-4653-8d27-24ef282a07e5: Incorrect because the distribution of income (and wealth) lies within the purview of fiscal policy involving the government’s decisions concerning spending and taxes. By contrast, monetary policy refers to central bank activities directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. Income distribution is not a policy domain of monetary policy.

entry.title: ITEM_20190530006
entry.itemBody: The government embarks on a policy intended to reduce the budget deficit. This is most likely:

answerFeedback.15ea505f-2b5b-41d7-8b09-ffd2c5ff1131: Incorrect. Reducing the budget deficit would slow the economy, not expand it.
answerFeedback.6d363223-058c-4357-b32e-5c90284a358c: Correct. A policy intended to reduce a budget deficit would involve raising taxes and/or reducing spending. Either action is fiscal and would likely cause the economy to slow, which is contractionary.
answerFeedback.86be8722-1105-4bc0-b600-2877f03f47b9: Incorrect. Quantitative easing is an action of monetary policy and does not address the budget deficit, which is a fiscal issue.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Bailey-01
entry.itemBody: Fiscal policy refers to the government's decisions about:

answerFeedback.0697de0c-6d2e-4068-b0a3-27d387bbf8b1: Correct because fiscal policy refers to the government's decisions about taxation and spending.
answerFeedback.7ea4aa18-b945-405c-8894-bbe637053126: Incorrect because monetary policy refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. By contrast, fiscal policy refers to the government's decisions about taxation and spending.
answerFeedback.afa3903f-0987-4a8c-a824-26d657a0faad: Incorrect because fiscal policy refers to the government's decisions about taxation and spending.

choices.itemBody: C. taxation, spending, and the quantity of money in the economy.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Econ-Crutu-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following economic policies is most likely directed toward influencing the quantity of credit in an economy?

answerFeedback.19eefdc5-ae2f-480a-8a91-e0b7175d91a0: Incorrect because fiscal policy refers to the government’s decisions about taxation and spending and it is not directly related to the quantity of credit in an economy.
answerFeedback.38266f75-bb4c-441c-86db-98a8f4fdbbe8: Incorrect because fiscal policy refers to the government’s decisions about taxation and spending and it is not directly related to the quantity of credit in an economy.
answerFeedback.9d68ee5b-69ef-4441-be27-2a411febe9fd: Correct because monetary policy refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy.

choices.itemBody: C. Both fiscal policy and monetary policy

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Econ-Islam-09
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely an objective of fiscal policy?

answerFeedback.110855ce-0fe4-4f81-a760-14b59888b6c5: Incorrect because targeting exchange rates is a part of monetary not fiscal policy. Many developing economies choose to operate monetary policy by targeting their currency’s exchange rate, rather than an explicit level of domestic inflation.
answerFeedback.b02d7c48-6c3d-416f-bd81-64cfd528f341: Correct because the tools associated with fiscal policy involve the use of government spending and changing tax revenue to affect a number of aspects of the economy: including the overall level of aggregate demand in an economy and hence the level of economic activity.
answerFeedback.e2f53447-426d-4b0f-b6a7-8ce113edff21: Incorrect because ensuring price stability is an objective of monetary policy not fiscal policy. There is one overarching objective [of the central bank] that most seem to acknowledge explicitly, and that is the objective of maintaining price stability.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Econ-Zipp-11
entry.itemBody: An objective of fiscal policy is to:

answerFeedback.398ed886-7b0d-456a-809a-057b76dee3c7: Correct because fiscal policy involves the use of government spending and changing tax revenue to affect a number of aspects of the economy including the distribution of income and wealth among different segments of the population.
answerFeedback.e3e3240a-cb8a-46f8-83b7-5fec843560bb: Incorrect because monetary policy, not fiscal policy, refers to central bank activities such as supervising the banking system.
answerFeedback.eadaed1a-bfa6-4232-aa53-b5bd1322a721: Incorrect because monetary policy refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. By contrast, fiscal policy refers to the government’s decisions about taxation and spending.

choices.itemBody: B. influence the quantity of credit in an economy.
C. distribute income among different segments of the population.
